title: 106_s2463
content: The Act titled "National Death Penalty Moratorium Act of 2000" establishes a moratorium on the death penalty. Congress finds that death sentences are disproportionately imposed on the poor and certain racial and ethnic groups, with African-Americans being overrepresented in executions and on death row. No state meets the American Bar Association's standards for providing counsel to indigent prisoners facing capital charges. Americans account for a significant percentage of executions and death row inmates, with a disproportionate number of African-American and Hispanic defendants facing capital prosecution. Racial disparities in the criminal justice system have been reported, leading to increased risk of imprisonment and execution of innocent individuals. The criminal justice system shows racial disparities in charging, sentencing, and the death penalty. Prisoner appeals have been limited, increasing the risk of imprisoning and executing innocent people. The Supreme Court has restricted death row prisoners' rights to appeal convictions, and new legislation in 1996 further limited Federal court review of death penalty appeals. The Federal and State death penalty is on hold until Congress reviews the National Commission on the Death Penalty's findings and recommendations. The Commission's guidelines and procedures will be either implemented or rejected through legislation. The National Commission on the Death Penalty is established with 15 members appointed by the President. The members include prosecutors, defense attorneys, judges, law enforcement officials, and individuals with expertise in relevant matters. The National Commission on the Death Penalty consists of 15 members appointed by the President, including prosecutors, defense attorneys, judges, and individuals with expertise in relevant matters. The Commission aims to have a balanced membership with diverse viewpoints on the use of the death penalty. The National Commission on the Death Penalty, consisting of 15 members appointed by the President, aims to have balanced viewpoints on the use of the death penalty. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled promptly, and meetings are held as needed with a majority required for quorum. The National Commission on the Death Penalty, comprised of 15 members appointed by the President, will convene its initial meeting. The Commission will meet as called by the Chairperson, with a majority forming a quorum. The President will appoint a member to serve as the Chair, and the Commission will establish rules and procedures for its proceedings. SEC. 202. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with conducting a comprehensive study on the administration of the death penalty to ensure it aligns with constitutional principles of fairness, justice, and due process. This study includes examining racial disparities, geographic and income-based disproportionality in capital cases, and the adequacy of legal representation for defendants. The Commission is examining the adequacy of legal representation for capital defendants, including adherence to ABA guidelines and policies. They are also investigating wrongful convictions, federal involvement in states without the death penalty, judicial review of constitutional claims, and the treatment of mentally disabled and juvenile offenders. The Commission is studying legal representation for capital defendants, wrongful convictions, federal involvement in states without the death penalty, judicial review of constitutional claims, and the treatment of mentally disabled and juvenile offenders. They are also examining procedures to ensure access to forensic evidence and fair administration of death penalty cases. The Commission will establish guidelines and procedures for the administration of the death penalty based on their study. The Commission will establish guidelines and procedures for the fair and impartial administration of the death penalty, ensuring due process, minimizing the risk of executing innocent individuals, and preventing racial discrimination. A preliminary report will be submitted to the President, Attorney General, and Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. The Commission will submit a preliminary report within one year and a final report within two years of the Act's enactment, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions to address racial discrimination in the administration of the death penalty. The Commission is granted powers under Section 203. The Commission may obtain information from Federal and State agencies, use postal services, accept gifts, and conduct hearings as necessary to fulfill its duties under this title. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and issue subpoenas to compel witnesses to testify or produce documents. Subpoenas must be signed by the Chairperson and can be enforced by the district court in case of non-compliance. The district court can issue an order for a person to testify or produce evidence in response to a subpoena. Failure to comply may result in contempt charges. Additionally, a court can issue a writ of habeas corpus ad testificandum to produce a person in custody before the Commission. Witness allowances and fees are governed by section 1821 of title 28, United States Code. The custodian must produce a person before the Commission as per a writ of habeas corpus ad testificandum. Witness allowances and fees are governed by section 1821 of title 28, United States Code. SEC. 204. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission serve without compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and necessary personnel without following civil service laws, and set their compensation. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and other personnel, set their compensation without following civil service laws, and may detail Federal Government employees without reimbursement. Additionally, the Chairperson can procure temporary and intermittent services at specified rates. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to procure temporary and intermittent services at specified rates under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report. It may spend up to $850,000 for its operations, funded by the Department of Justice.
